questions.text: Farmer with traumatic ulcer in eye and septate hyphae seen. Causative organism is ? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Aspergillus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Farmers often suffer from injuries involving organic matter. The presence of a traumatic ulcer in the eye coupled with the identification of septate hyphae points toward a fungal infection.
  • • Between Mucor and Aspergillus, the distinguishing factor is the type of hyphae. Aspergillus forms septate hyphae, meaning the hyphae have regular, cross-wall divisions. In contrast, Mucor forms aseptate (or coenocytic) hyphae, which lack these septa.
  • • Characteristic of Hyphae -
  • • Characteristic of Hyphae -
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Mucor: Although Mucor is a fungus that can cause infections, it forms aseptate hyphae. This characteristic helps differentiate it from Aspergillus in cases of fungal eye infections.
  • • Option A. Mucor:
  • • Option C. Streptococcus pyogenes: This bacterium can cause various infections, including those in the eye, but it does not form hyphae. Thus, it cannot be the causative organism in this scenario.
  • • Option C. Streptococcus pyogenes:
  • • Option D. Pseudomonas: This is another bacterium that can cause eye infections, particularly in the context of contact lens wearers, but like Streptococcus pyogenes, it does not form hyphae.
  • • Option D. Pseudomonas:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of septate hyphae in an eye infection suggests Aspergillus as the causative organism.

questions.text: A kinyoun positive oocyst (25 m) was isolated from an HIV patient with diarrhea. Identify the organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cystoisospora

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Comparison of coccidian parasites causing diarrhea in an immunocompromised host:

questions.text: A stool sample is collected. The specimen is processed for examination and is labeled at different levels as A, B, C, and D. Identify the level at which parasitic ova will be seen when viewed under a microscope? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In the formal ether sedimentation technique, parasitic ova, cysts, and larvae will be concentrated in the sediment at the bottom of the tube, labeled as level D. This sediment is where parasitic elements are found and examined under a microscope.

questions.text: Identify the pathognomonic structure seen in this skin biopsy from a patient with persistent subcutaneous nodules along the lymphatics: (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The asteroid body is a diagnostic hallmark of Sporothrix schenckii infection. It appears as a central fungal spore surrounded by radiating eosinophilic material, forming a star-shaped structure due to the Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon . This is characteristic of sporotrichosis , which typically presents as subcutaneous nodules spreading along lymphatic channels.
  • • asteroid body
  • • Splendore-Hoeppli phenomenon
  • • sporotrichosis
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Copper pennies – These are sclerotic bodies (medlar bodies) , which are thick-walled, brown, septate fungal structures resembling coins. They are pathognomonic for chromoblastomycosis , not sporotrichosis. Option C: Figure of 8 appearance –Under the microscope, the budding yeast of Blastomyces sometimes resembles a "figure 8" due to its broad attachment between the mother and daughter cell during replication. Option D: Pilot wheel – The "pilot wheel" or "captain's wheel" structure is associated with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis . The fungal yeast form has a large, central mother cell with multiple buds symmetrically arranged around it, resembling the spokes of a ship’s wheel. This is characteristic of paracoccidioidomycosis .
  • • Option A: Copper pennies – These are sclerotic bodies (medlar bodies) , which are thick-walled, brown, septate fungal structures resembling coins. They are pathognomonic for chromoblastomycosis , not sporotrichosis.
  • • Option A: Copper pennies
  • • sclerotic bodies (medlar bodies)
  • • chromoblastomycosis
  • • Option C: Figure of 8 appearance –Under the microscope, the budding yeast of Blastomyces sometimes resembles a "figure 8" due to its broad attachment between the mother and daughter cell during replication.
  • • Option C: Figure of 8 appearance
  • • Option D: Pilot wheel – The "pilot wheel" or "captain's wheel" structure is associated with Paracoccidioides brasiliensis . The fungal yeast form has a large, central mother cell with multiple buds symmetrically arranged around it, resembling the spokes of a ship’s wheel. This is characteristic of paracoccidioidomycosis .
  • • Option D: Pilot wheel
  • • paracoccidioidomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The asteroid body is a pathognomonic structure for Sporothrix schenckii infection, especially in lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis, presenting as subcutaneous nodules along the lymphatic channels.
  • ➤ asteroid body

questions.text: Which method of diagnosis is shown in the image? ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Darkfield microscopy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Darkfield microscopy is identified by its characteristic bright specimen against a dark background and is commonly used for diagnosing syphilis through visualization of spirochetes.

questions.text: Which virus can be identified by a PCR method and is endemic to India? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) West Nile Virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ West Nile Virus (WNV) can be identified by PCR and is endemic to India, with significant historical and ongoing presence, making it a critical pathogen for regional public health monitoring and response.

questions.text: Which of the following is the primary identification made by a CBNAAT or GeneXpert? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as GeneXpert, is a molecular diagnostic test used for the detection of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin.
  • • The key points are:
  • • The key points are:
  • • CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection limit à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen) In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.
  • • CBNAAT or GeneXpert is a molecular method based on real-time PCR that can detect the presence of MTB. (Detection limit à about 131 bacilli/mL of specimen)
  • • In addition to detecting MTB, it can also detect resistance to the drug rifampicin by identifying mutations in the rpoB gene, which is associated with rifampicin resistance
  • • CBNAAT/GeneXpert primarily identifies the presence of MTB and rifampicin resistance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other
  • • Options:
  • • Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis: While CBNAAT can detect the presence of MTB, it also provides information on rifampicin resistance, making this option incomplete.
  • • Option A. Mycobacterium tuberculosis:
  • • Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance: CBNAAT does not directly detect resistance to isoniazid, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.
  • • Option C. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Isoniazid resistance:
  • • Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance: CBNAAT does not detect resistance to ethambutol, another first-line anti-tubercular drug.
  • • Option D. MTB + Rifampicin resistance + Ethambutol resistance:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT or GeneXpert) is a molecular diagnostic tool that primarily identifies the presence of Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) and its resistance to the anti-tubercular drug rifampicin by detecting mutations in the rpoB gene.
  • ➤ Additional Information –
  • ➤ Additional Information –

questions.text: A patient addressing from Delhi presents with fever, arthralgia, and extensive petechial rash for 3 days. Lab investigations revealed a hemoglobin of 9 g/dL, a white blood cell count of 9000 cells/mm3, a platelet count of 20000 cells/mm3, and a prolonged bleeding time. The clotting time was normal. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dengue

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of fever, arthralgia, petechial rash, and significant thrombocytopenia in a patient from an area where dengue is endemic should prompt immediate consideration of dengue fever, with prompt initiation of supportive care and monitoring for potential complications such as DHF or DSS.

questions.text: Identify the organism from the given image? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leptospira

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leptospira is identified by its spiral morphology with axial filaments (endoflagella) and is a type of spirochete, along with Treponema and Borrelia.
  • ➤ Endoflagella are seen in:
  • ➤ Endoflagella are seen in:
  • ➤ Treponema Borrelia Leptospira
  • ➤ Treponema
  • ➤ Borrelia
  • ➤ Leptospira

questions.text: Which of the following causes aplastic crisis in hereditary spherocytosis? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Parvovirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 is the causative agent for aplastic crisis in patients with hereditary spherocytosis. It infects erythroid progenitor cells, inhibiting erythropoiesis and leading to a significant decrease in reticulocytes, causing acute erythroblastopenia.

questions.text: The toxin produced by the organisms shown below acts via? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) ADP ribosylation of EF2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Diphtheria toxin acts by ADP-ribosylating elongation factor 2 (EF-2), thereby inhibiting protein synthesis and leading to cell death.

questions.text: Which protein is present in the HPV vaccine? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) L1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The HPV vaccine contains the L1 protein, which forms virus-like particles that induce an immune response to prevent infection by various HPV types, significantly reducing the risk of HPV-associated cancers and genital warts.

questions.text: A militant presents with rashes all over his body sparing the palms and soles. On examination, he was febrile and lice were noted. Which of the following is responsible for his condition? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rickettsia prowazekii

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Rickettsia prowazekii, transmitted by body lice, causes epidemic typhus, which is characterized by a rash that begins on the trunk and spreads to the extremities while sparing the face, palms, and soles. Awareness of this disease's clinical features and transmission methods is essential for preventing outbreaks in high-risk environments.

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in patients presenting with symptoms like fever, jaundice, red eyes, and hematuria, as it accurately detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira, confirming the infection.

questions.text: The causative agent for St. Anthony's Fire is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Streptococcus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • St. Anthony’s Fire, also known as erysipelas, is primarily caused by Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes). Erysipelas is an acute infection affecting the superficial layers of the skin, particularly the dermis, and is characterized by a sharply defined, bright red, and swollen area of skin. The infection also involves prominent lymphatic involvement. The term "St. Anthony's Fire" dates back to the Middle Ages, when it was mistakenly thought to be caused by the ingestion of ergot-contaminated rye.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B . Staphylococcus: Staphylococcus species, particularly Staphylococcus aureus, are common causes of various skin infections, but they are not typically associated with erysipelas.
  • • Option B
  • • Staphylococcus:
  • • Option C . Klebsiella: Klebsiella species are gram-negative bacteria that can cause a range of infections, including pneumonia and urinary tract infections, but they are not linked to erysipelas.
  • • Option C
  • • Klebsiella:
  • • Option D . Nocardia: Nocardia species are bacteria that can cause nocardiosis, a serious infection that can affect the lungs, brain, and skin, but they are not responsible for erysipelas.
  • • Option D
  • • Nocardia:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Erysipelas, also known as St. Anthony's Fire, is caused by Group A beta-hemolytic streptococci

questions.text: Which plasmodium species affects the brain? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Plasmodium species that affects the brain and can cause cerebral malaria is Plasmodium falciparum.
  • • Among the four major Plasmodium species that cause malaria (P. vivax, P. falciparum, P. malariae, and P. ovale), only P. falciparum is associated with cerebral malaria.
  • • While all Plasmodium species can cause malaria symptoms like fever, anemia, and splenomegaly, complications like cerebral malaria are caused specifically by P. falciparum.
  • • Pernicious malaria - (due to heavy parasitization)
  • • Pernicious malaria - (due to heavy parasitization)
  • • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs
  • • In cerebral malaria, P. falciparum parasites invade and clog the cerebral blood vessels, leading to brain involvement, hyperpyrexia, coma and paralysis
  • • Algid malaria: characterized by cold clammy skin leading to peripheral circulatory failure
  • • Septicemic malaria: characterized by high continuous fever with involvement of various organs
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. P. vivax, C. P. malariae, and D. P. ovale: These species can cause uncomplicated malaria but do not typically affect the brain or lead to cerebral malaria.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum is the only Plasmodium species that can cause cerebral malaria, a potentially life-threatening complication in which the parasites invade and clog the brain's blood vessels.

questions.text: SARS-Cov-2 can be detected by all except? ( INICET NOVEMBER 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Real-time PCR to detect viral mRNA

options.label: C
options.text: Rapid antigen test to detect spike proteins

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Southern blotting

Explanation:

  • • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR) :
  • • Real-time PCR (RT-PCR)
  • • Method : This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.
  • • Method : This technique is used to detect the presence of viral RNA. Nasopharyngeal swabs are typically used as the sample source.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.
  • • Explanation : It is the most sensitive and specific test available for SARS-CoV-2 detection.
  • • Explanation
  • • Rapid Antigen Test :
  • • Rapid Antigen Test
  • • Method : This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • • Method : This test detects specific proteins, such as the spike protein, from the virus present in nasopharyngeal secretions.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.
  • • Explanation : It provides quicker results compared to PCR but is generally less sensitive.
  • • Explanation
  • • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay) :
  • • ELISA (Enzyme-Linked Immunosorbent Assay)
  • • Method : This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.
  • • Method : This technique detects antibodies against spike proteins or the spike proteins themselves.
  • • Method
  • • Explanation : It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.
  • • Explanation : It is used for both diagnostic and serological purposes.
  • • Explanation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Southern blotting is not a suitable method for detecting SARS-CoV-2 as it is designed to detect DNA, while SARS-CoV-2 is an RNA virus and requires RNA-specific detection techniques.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified as a Category B bioterrorism agent? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Coxiella burnetti, the causative agent of Q fever, is classified as a Category B bioterrorism agent by the CDC. Category B agents are moderately easy to disseminate, cause moderate morbidity and low mortality, and require enhanced disease surveillance.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B) Variola virus: This is a Category A agent that causes smallpox. It has high potential for mass casualties and requires special public health preparedness.
  • • Option B) Variola virus:
  • • Option C) Ebola virus: This is a Category A agent due to its high mortality rate, potential for public panic, and requirement for special public health preparedness.
  • • Option C) Ebola virus:
  • • Option D) Bacillus anthracis: This is a Category A agent due to its ease of dissemination, high mortality rate (especially in inhalational form), and potential for causing public panic.
  • • Option D) Bacillus anthracis:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the CDC's classification of bioterrorism agents:
  • ➤ Category A: Highest priority (easily disseminated, high mortality) Category B: Moderate priority (moderately easy to disseminate, moderate morbidity, low mortality) Category C: Emerging threats (potential for future weaponization)
  • ➤ Category A: Highest priority (easily disseminated, high mortality)
  • ➤ Category B: Moderate priority (moderately easy to disseminate, moderate morbidity, low mortality)
  • ➤ Category C: Emerging threats (potential for future weaponization)

questions.text: A patient presented with a prolonged fever of unknown origin (PUO), raising suspicion of brucellosis. To confirm the diagnosis, various dilutions of the patient's serum sample are prepared for a standard agglutination test. The outcome is as follows: No agglutination is observed at serum dilutions of 1:20 and 1:40, while positive agglutination occurs at dilutions of 1:80 and 1:160. What factor is accountable for the lack of agglutination in the initial two dilutions? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Antibody excess

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The prozone phenomenon, where antibody excess prevents agglutination, can account for the lack of agglutination in low dilution samples.

questions.text: A photographer who recently returned from Africa presents to the emergency department with abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, and hemorrhagic manifestations. He died despite treatment, and an autopsy revealed intranuclear Torres bodies in the liver. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented it? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 17D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The 17D vaccine could have prevented the yellow fever that led to the photographer's severe symptoms and death. This highlights the importance of appropriate vaccination before traveling to areas where yellow fever is endemic.

options.label: D

questions.text: The test shown in the image below. Which uses a bacitracin disk, is useful in identifying? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Streptococcus pyogenes

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The bacitracin disk test is used to identify Streptococcus pyogenes (Group A Streptococcus), which is characterized by its sensitivity to bacitracin and beta-hemolytic activity on blood agar. This test differentiates S. pyogenes from other beta-hemolytic streptococci, which are resistant to bacitracin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the given image is correct? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Albendazole is the drug of choice

options.label: B
options.text: Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans

options.label: C
options.text: Infection is acquired by ingestion of aquatic plants

questions.correct_answer: B. Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Majority of infections are asymptomatic in humans

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) is the most common and smallest tapeworm in humans. Majority of infections are asymptomatic. The drug of choice is praziquantel .

questions.text: Which of the following is best for the malaria species identification? ( INICET May 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male who has been admitted with symptoms of altered sensorium and hydrophobia, indicating a potential case of rabies, you have obtained corneal scrapings for further investigation. Now, which test would you select to establish a conclusive diagnosis of the condition? ( INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Viral Culture

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Viral culture from corneal scrapings is the most definitive test for diagnosing rabies in a patient presenting with altered sensorium and hydrophobia.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: A resident had a needle stick injury while dealing with a Hepatitis B positive patient. Serology was done and HBsAg was negative and the Anti-HBs was >105 mIU/ml. What is the next step of management? ( INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: D
options.text: No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

questions.correct_answer: D. No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) No treatment required as he already has Hep B antibody titres from vaccination

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

questions.text: A patient from Uttar Pradesh presented with fever, pallor, and hepatosplenomegaly. Peripheral smear examination showed pancytopenia. Buffy coat examination showed macrophages laden with organisms with a kinetoplast. What is the vector for the likely disease? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Sandfly

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Visceral leishmaniasis, caused by Leishmania donovani and transmitted by sandflies, is a severe systemic disease. Recognizing its epidemiology, clinical presentation, and diagnostic features is crucial for prompt diagnosis and treatment. Awareness and control of the vector, along with appropriate medical intervention, are essential in areas endemic for this disease.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Coxsackievirus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Coxsackievirus is the causative agent of hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa.
  • ➤ Palms and Soles rash is seen in – CARS

questions.text: The culture from a pustular lesion showed hemolytic gram-positive cocci. A provisional diagnosis of Group A streptococcal pyoderma can be made by:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Group A streptococci (Streptococcus pyogenes) are beta-hemolytic, gram-positive cocci. They can be differentiated from other hemolytic streptococci, such as Group B streptococci (S. agalactiae), using the bacitracin sensitivity test. S. pyogenes is sensitive to bacitracin, which inhibits its growth, making this test a key diagnostic tool. When bacitracin is applied to a culture, S. pyogenes shows a zone of inhibition around the bacitracin disk, confirming its identity.
  • • Differentiation Tests:
  • • Differentiation Tests:
  • • Catalase test: Differentiates Streptococci from Staphylococci. Bacitracin test: Differentiates Group A Streptococci from other Beta-hemolytic Streptococci. Optochin test: Differentiates Pneumococci from other Alpha-hemolytic Streptococci. Coagulase test: Differentiates Staphylococcus aureus from other Staphylococci.
  • • Catalase test: Differentiates Streptococci from Staphylococci.
  • • Catalase test:
  • • Bacitracin test: Differentiates Group A Streptococci from other Beta-hemolytic Streptococci.
  • • Bacitracin test:
  • • Optochin test: Differentiates Pneumococci from other Alpha-hemolytic Streptococci.
  • • Optochin test:
  • • Coagulase test: Differentiates Staphylococcus aureus from other Staphylococci.
  • • Coagulase test:
  • • Approach to patient showing Gram-positive cocci:
  • • Approach to patient showing Gram-positive cocci:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A . Catalase positivity: This test differentiates streptococci (catalase-negative) from staphylococci (catalase-positive). Since the bacteria in question are streptococci, catalase positivity is not applicable.
  • • Option A
  • • Catalase positivity:
  • • Option B . Optochin sensitivity: This test is used to differentiate Streptococcus pneumoniae (optochin-sensitive) from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. It does not apply to beta-hemolytic streptococci like S. pyogenes.
  • • Option B
  • • Optochin sensitivity:
  • • Option C . Bile solubility: This test also differentiates S. pneumoniae (bile-soluble) from other alpha-hemolytic streptococci. It is not relevant for identifying beta-hemolytic streptococci.
  • • Option C
  • • Bile solubility:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Group A streptococci (S. pyogenes) can be provisionally diagnosed using the bacitracin sensitivity test, which is a differentiating factor from other beta-hemolytic streptococci.

questions.text: Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to the absence of? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) T cell

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nude mice lack a thymus, resulting in a deficiency of mature T cells, which are essential for rejecting xenografts. This highlights the crucial role of T cells in adaptive immune responses and graft rejection.

questions.text: A patient who was on steroids for the treatment of chronic urticaria presents to the emergency department with acute worsening of respiratory symptoms. He says that he has been having nocturnal cough for last several weeks. A hemogram revealed elevated eosinophils. Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) specimen following bronchoscopy showed the presence of certain larvae as shown in the image below. Identify the causative organism: (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Strongyloides stercoralis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In patients presenting with respiratory symptoms and eosinophilia, especially those who are immunocompromised, strongyloidiasis should be considered. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent the severe outcomes associated with hyperinfection. Treatment typically involves antiparasitic medications such as ivermectin.
  • ➤ Autoinfection: - CHEST (Mnemonic)
  • ➤ Autoinfection:
  • ➤ Cryptosporidium parvum H. nana larva Enterobius vermicularis Strongyloides Taenia solium
  • ➤ Cryptosporidium parvum
  • ➤ H. nana larva
  • ➤ Enterobius vermicularis
  • ➤ Strongyloides
  • ➤ Taenia solium

questions.text: Match the following: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) a-3, b-1, c-4, d-2

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the nucleic acid composition of viruses is crucial. Rotavirus has dsRNA, SARS-CoV-2 has ssRNA, Parvovirus has ssDNA, and HPV has dsDNA.

questions.text: Patient came with fever and chills. Peripheral smear shown in the image. Choose the pathogen: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasmodium falciparum can be distinguished by the presence of multiple rings in a single RBC and the characteristic headphone-like accolé form.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Legionella

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ BCYE medium is essential for the successful isolation and culture of Legionella species, particularly Legionella pneumophila, from environmental and clinical specimens. This medium meets the specific nutritional requirements and provides a protective environment for the growth of this pathogen.

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nipah virus should be considered when a patient, especially in South Asia, presents with fever, respiratory symptoms, and encephalitis, and has a history of exposure to fruit bats

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of Mollicutes? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Mollicutes is a class of bacteria distinguished by the absence of a cell wall. The most well-known genera in this class are Mycoplasma and Ureaplasma , with Ureaplasma urealyticum being a notable example that causes non-gonococcal urethritis.
  • ➤ Mollicutes
  • ➤ Mycoplasma
  • ➤ Ureaplasma
  • ➤ Ureaplasma urealyticum

questions.text: Which extracellular cell adhesion is disrupted by Vibrio cholerae? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Occludens

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Vibrio cholerae disrupts occludens, specifically targeting tight junctions between intestinal epithelial cells, which impairs their barrier function.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Integrin : Primarily involved in cell-extracellular matrix adhesion, not typically disrupted by Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option A. Integrin
  • • Option B. Cadherin : Important for cell-cell adhesion in adherens junctions, not the main target of Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option B. Cadherin
  • • Option D. None of the above : Incorrect, as occludens are indeed affected by Vibrio cholerae.
  • • Option D. None of the above

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Vibrio cholerae specifically targets occludens, which are crucial components of tight junctions, thereby compromising intestinal epithelial barrier functions.

questions.text: Pencil shaped macroconidia are seen in? ( FMGE July 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Trichophyton

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pencil-shaped macroconidia are a distinguishing feature of the fungus Trichophyton. Trichophyton is one of the three genera of dermatophytes, which also include Microsporum and Epidermophyton.
  • • Dermatophytes cause infections known as dermatophytosis or ringworm, which affect keratinized tissues such as the skin, hair, and nails.
  • • Dermatophytosis can be classified into three species:
  • • Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails. The macroconidia are pencil-shaped, and the microconidia are round to piriform (pear-shaped). In the case of Trichophyton, the macroconidia are elongated and resemble pencils. This characteristic helps in differentiating it from other dermatophytes. Microsporum: Primarily involves skin and hair. The macroconidia are spindle-shaped and spiny, while microconidia are usually absent. Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. The macroconidia are club-shaped, and microconidia are absent.
  • • Trichophyton: Involves skin, hair, and nails. The macroconidia are pencil-shaped, and the microconidia are round to piriform (pear-shaped). In the case of Trichophyton, the macroconidia are elongated and resemble pencils. This characteristic helps in differentiating it from other dermatophytes.
  • • Trichophyton:
  • • Microsporum: Primarily involves skin and hair. The macroconidia are spindle-shaped and spiny, while microconidia are usually absent.
  • • Microsporum:
  • • Epidermophyton: Involves skin and nails. The macroconidia are club-shaped, and microconidia are absent.
  • • Epidermophyton:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Microsporum: The macroconidia of Microsporum are spindle-shaped and spiny, not pencil-shaped. This genus primarily affects skin and hair.
  • • Option B. Microsporum:
  • • Option C. Epidermophyton: The macroconidia of Epidermophyton are club-shaped, not pencil-shaped. This genus affects skin and nails.
  • • Option C. Epidermophyton:
  • • Option D. Clostridium: This is a genus of bacteria, not fungi, and it does not produce macroconidia. Clostridium species are known for producing spores, not conidia.
  • • Option D. Clostridium:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pencil-shaped macroconidia are characteristic of Trichophyton, a genus of dermatophytes that affects skin, hair, and nails.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not transmitted by the vector shown below? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Orientia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Orientia, the causative agent of scrub typhus, is transmitted by chigger mites, not by the tick shown in the image.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Babesia : Transmitted by ticks
  • • Option B. Babesia
  • • Option C. Ehrlichia : Also transmitted by ticks
  • • Option C. Ehrlichia
  • • Option D . Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever : Also transmitted by ticks
  • • Option D
  • • Crimean congo hemorrhagic fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Orientia tsutsugamushi, responsible for scrub typhus, is not transmitted by ticks but by chigger mites, distinguishing it from other tick-borne infections like Babesia and Ehrlichia.

questions.text: True about Rotavirus vaccine is all except? (Twisted PYQ)

options.label: C
options.text: Can be given up to 32 weeks

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Rotavirus vaccine can be safely co-administered with OPV. In fact, concurrent administration of rotavirus vaccine with other routine infant vaccines, including OPV, is recommended by WHO and has shown no interference with the immune response to either vaccine.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Live attenuated vaccine: This is correct. Rotavirus vaccines (both RotaTeq and Rotarix) contain live attenuated virus strains.
  • • Option A) Live attenuated vaccine:
  • • Option B) Oral route: This is correct. The vaccine is administered orally to mimic natural infection and induce mucosal immunity.
  • • Option B) Oral route:
  • • Option C) Can be given up to 32 weeks: This is correct. While the first dose should be administered before 15 weeks of age, the vaccination schedule can be completed up to 32 weeks of age according to current guidelines.
  • • Option C) Can be given up to 32 weeks:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To understand the key characteristics of rotavirus vaccine administration, including its compatibility with other vaccines, the importance of age-specific scheduling, and its nature as a live attenuated oral vaccine. This also emphasizes the importance of integrated vaccine delivery in routine immunization programs.

questions.text: Which toxin acts via the mechanism depicted in the image below? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Botulinum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin causes flaccid paralysis by preventing the release of acetylcholine at peripheral nerve endings through the proteolysis of SNARE proteins necessary for acetylcholine vesicle exocytosis.

questions.text: A 35-year-old HIV positive patient presents with mucosal lesions in the mouth as shown in the image below. On microscopy, budding yeasts and pseudohyphae are seen. What is the likely diagnosis? ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oral candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Oral candidiasis is a common opportunistic infection in HIV-positive individuals, characterized by white, patchy lesions in the oral cavity and the presence of Candida species on microscopic examination. Recognizing this condition and distinguishing it from other oral lesions based on clinical presentation and risk factors is crucial for appropriate management, which may include antifungal therapies like nystatin, ketoconazole, or fluconazole.

questions.text: Identify the helminth from the life cycle given below? ( INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Strongyloides stercoralis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Strongyloides stercoralis infects through skin penetration by filariform larvae from contaminated soil.

questions.text: A farmer from the sub-Himalayan belt had a thorn prick injury a year back and developed a warty, verrucous growth at the site of prick. A skin biopsy sample was taken and sent for histopathological examination. The characteristic microscopic body as shown in the image was seen. Which of the following could be the most likely diagnosis? (INICET MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Chromoblastomycosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Chromoblastomycosis is characterized by a slowly spreading warty, verrucous lesion following a thorn prick injury, with histopathological evidence of medlar bodies.

questions.text: Identify the component responsible for endotoxic shock in gram-negative bacteria? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins
  • ➤ Differences between exotoxins and endotoxins

questions.text: Which of the following cells is activated when there is absence or downregulation of MHC class I molecules on cell surface? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • NK cells are activated by the absence or downregulation of MHC class I molecules on cell surfaces ("missing self" hypothesis). When virally infected or transformed cells attempt to evade cytotoxic T cell recognition by reducing MHC class I expression, NK cells recognize this absence and become activated to kill these cells. This is mediated through inhibitory receptors on NK cells that normally bind to MHC class I - when MHC class I is missing, the inhibitory signal is lost, leading to NK cell activation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Helper T cells: These CD4+ cells are activated by antigens presented via MHC class II molecules on antigen-presenting cells, not by the absence of MHC class I.
  • • Option A) Helper T cells:
  • • Option B) Cytotoxic T cells: CD8+ T cells require the presence, not absence, of MHC class I presenting specific antigens for their activation. They are inhibited when MHC class I is downregulated.
  • • Option B) Cytotoxic T cells:
  • • Option D) B cells: These cells recognize free antigens through their B cell receptors and require help from CD4+ T cells that recognize antigens presented on MHC class II. They are not directly influenced by MHC class I levels.
  • • Option D) B cells:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The unique mechanism of NK cell activation through the "missing self" hypothesis and how it complements cytotoxic T cell responses in immune surveillance against virally infected or transformed cells.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trichomonas vaginalis? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

options.label: C
options.text: Cysts are seen on wet saline mount of vaginal secretions

options.label: D
options.text: It is not a sexually transmitted infection

questions.correct_answer: B. Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Twitching motility is seen on wet saline mount

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A HIV patient is presenting with cough without sputum, on examination his CD4 counts were <100 and chest x ray shown bilateral infiltration of lung, on further proceeding Bronchoalveolar lavage is done and the organisms were positive for acid fast staining, what is the organism responsible for his condition? (FMGE JANUARY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Mycobacterium avium complex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In HIV patients with CD4 counts <100 cells/µL presenting with a cough without sputum, bilateral lung infiltrates on chest x-ray, and positive acid-fast staining, Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most likely causative organism.

questions.text: Which of the following is Burkholderia cepacia resistant to? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cefotetan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Burkholderia cepacia exhibits resistance to several antibiotic classes, including second-generation cephalosporins like cefotetan.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presented with retro-orbital pain, conjunctival suffusion, night fever and chills, calf tenderness, cervical lymphadenopathy, hypokalemia, and joint pain. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Conjunctival suffusion is a distinguishing symptom of Leptospirosis and is not commonly seen in Dengue or other similar infectious conditions.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the clinic with complaints of abdominal pain, fatigue, and weight loss and looked jaundiced. Upon further investigation, you suspect a parasitic infection. You obtain a stool sample and operculated eggs in the feces. Further examination reveals the presence of a parasite with a complex life cycle with snail and plants as the intermediate host. Which parasite is most likely responsible for the above symptoms? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fasciola hepatica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Fasciola hepatica, the sheep liver fluke, is diagnosed by identifying eggs in the feces, and it has a complex life cycle involving snails and aquatic vegetation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.
  • ➤ Fasciola hepatica, the sheep liver fluke, is diagnosed by identifying eggs in the feces, and it has a complex life cycle involving snails and aquatic vegetation, making it the most likely cause of the described symptoms.

questions.text: Most common agent responsible for UTI in children is: (NEET PG 2014)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) E. coli

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • E. coli is the most frequent causative agent of urinary tract infections (UTIs) in children. It accounts for 80-85% of all UTIs due to its ability to adhere to the uroepithelium via specific adhesins and pili, which facilitate infection.
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Klebsiella: While Klebsiella can cause UTIs, it is less common compared to E. coli.
  • • Option B. Klebsiella:
  • • Option C. Pseudomonas: Pseudomonas is more commonly associated with complicated UTIs, especially in hospitalized or catheterized patients, rather than being the primary agent in children.
  • • Option C. Pseudomonas:
  • • Option D. Streptococcus: Streptococcus species are not a common cause of UTIs in children.
  • • Option D. Streptococcus:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • Educational objective:
  • • E. coli is the predominant pathogen responsible for urinary tract infections in children.

questions.text: Choose the wrong statement about Plasmodium species: (INICET MAY 2019)

options.label: A
options.text: Drug resistant falciparum is seen in India

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax

options.label: C
options.text: Severe malaria with shock is called algid malaria

options.label: D
options.text: Relapse is seen in P. ovale

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Presence of duffy blood group antigen is protective against vivax

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The absence of the Duffy blood group antigen is protective against Plasmodium vivax , not its presence.

questions.text: A 11-year-old child presents with high-grade fever, toxic appearance, and severe respiratory distress following mild upper respiratory symptoms. Chest X-ray shows subglottic narrowing with irregular tracheal margins and membrane-like opacities. Which organism is the most likely cause? (Twisted PYQ)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presentation describes bacterial tracheitis, typically caused by Staphylococcus aureus. This condition often follows a viral upper respiratory infection and is characterized by high-grade fever, toxic appearance, and severe respiratory distress. The X-ray shows subglottic narrowing with irregular tracheal margins and membrane-like opacities, distinguishing it from the smooth "steeple sign" of viral croup.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Parainfluenza virus: Causes viral croup with barking cough and stridor but presents with low-grade fever and less toxicity. X-ray shows classic smooth "steeple sign."
  • • Option A) Parainfluenza virus:
  • • Option C) Respiratory syncytial virus: Typically causes bronchiolitis in younger children with wheezing and crackles. X-ray shows hyperinflation and patchy infiltrates.
  • • Option C) Respiratory syncytial virus:
  • • Option D) Mycoplasma pneumoniae: Usually causes walking pneumonia with gradual onset, dry cough, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on X-ray.
  • • Option D) Mycoplasma pneumoniae:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To differentiate bacterial tracheitis from viral croup and other respiratory infections based on clinical presentation and radiological findings, emphasizing the more severe nature and different causative organism of bacterial tracheitis compared to viral respiratory infections.

questions.text: The transmission of infection during the perinatal period exhibits a range of symptoms, including anemia, potential myocarditis, high-output cardiac failure, and ascites. Identify the specific causative agent responsible for these manifestations: (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Parvovirus B19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Parvovirus B19 is responsible for severe anemia, hydrops fetalis, and other serious complications in fetuses.

questions.text: All of the following oncogenic viruses can integrate with the human genome to initiate carcinogenesis except: (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HTLV

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:
  • ➤ Oncogenic DNA and RNA Viruses:
  • ➤ Oncogenic DNA Viruses: EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) HPV (Human Papillomavirus) HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8) MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus) Oncogenic RNA Viruses: HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)
  • ➤ Oncogenic DNA Viruses: EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) HPV (Human Papillomavirus) HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8) MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • ➤ EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus) HBV (Hepatitis B Virus) HPV (Human Papillomavirus) HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8) MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • ➤ EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus)
  • ➤ HBV (Hepatitis B Virus)
  • ➤ HPV (Human Papillomavirus)
  • ➤ HHV-8 (Human Herpesvirus-8)
  • ➤ MCPyV (Merkel Cell Polyomavirus)
  • ➤ Oncogenic RNA Viruses: HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)
  • ➤ HCV (Hepatitis C Virus) HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)
  • ➤ HCV (Hepatitis C Virus)
  • ➤ HTLV-1 (Human T-cell Lymphotropic Virus-1)

questions.text: The life cycle of an organism is given below. Identify the vector involved? ( INICET MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
